coredata.dc:description: In the emerging landscape of Industry 5.0, the integration of innovative technologies such as Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) is pivotal for steering industrial processes towards sustainability and inclusivity, particularly in developing nations striving to align with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The study explores the transformative capabilities of CDTs in Industry 5.0, concentrating on India's quest for inclusive and sustainable industrialization in alignment with SDGs. The inclusion of the TOE-HOT framework enriches the research's analytical foundation, providing a nuanced perspective to investigate the multifaceted dynamics of technology, organization, environment, and human aspects within the sphere of industrial evolution. By employing the Best-Worst Method (BWM), Interpretive Structural Modelling (ISM), and MICMAC analysis, the study delves deep into the synergies between industrial strategies, technology, and sustainable development. The findings reveal the paramountcy of the Technological Dimension, emphasizing CDTs strategies like real-time optimization and data analytics, which are instrumental in dynamically adjusting manufacturing processes and fostering alignment with market demands. The research also stresses the roles of various CDTs strategies like strategic alignment, change management, job security, skill augmentation, and environmental compliance in industrial sustainability and inclusivity. The paper concludes with invaluable insights for policymakers, industry leaders, and researchers, emphasizing the necessity for a holistic, interconnected approach to fully harness the potential of CDTs in realizing the aspirations of Industry 5.0 and contributing to India's sustainable industrial advancement by 2030.

row.entry: CDTs can adjust manufacturing processes in real-time based on a host of variables, such as energy use, raw material availability, and production speed, to ensure that operations are as efficient and sustainable as possible.
He et al. (2021); Yitmen et al. (2021); Hu (2022) Maheshwari et al. (2023)

CDTs have the capability to analyze market trends, thereby helping industries to avoid both overproduction and stock-outs. This aligns production with actual demand, making industries more sustainable in the long run.
Rahmani et al. (2022); Zheng et al. (2022); Voipio et al. (2023)
By connecting various sensors and devices, CDTs can help monitor workplace conditions in real-time, ensuring that worker safety and well-being are prioritized, thereby contributing to inclusivity.
Keane et al. (2020); He et al. (2021); Shi et al. (2022); Longo et al. (2023)
The insights provided by CDTs can be pivotal in training employees about the importance of sustainability and inclusion, thus helping companies to manage changes in organizational culture.
Du et al. (2020); Lu et al. (2020); Yitmen et al. (2021); Zheng et al. (2022); Longo et al. (2023)

CDTs can be central to a firm's strategy for achieving sustainability. For example, companies can set specific sustainability metrics that are continuously monitored by the CDT, ensuring alignment with broader sustainable development goals.
Kalaboukas et al. (2023); Lv et al. (2023); Ãnal et al. (2023)
With real-time compliance tracking, CDTs can alert organizations to any breaches in environmental regulations or ethical norms, allowing for immediate corrective action.
Yitmen et al. (2021); Zheng et al. (2022); Ãnal et al. (2023); Kalaboukas et al. (2023)

One of the most immediate environmental benefits that CDTs can offer is in the real-time tracking of emissions and waste by-products. By setting emission thresholds, CDTs can alert the industry when limits are exceeded, allowing for immediate corrective actions that contribute to reducing the overall environmental footprint of the industry
Abburu et al. (2020); Leng et al. (2021); Hu et al. (2022); Kalaboukas et al. (2023)

CDTs can model the consumption rates of various resources like water, raw materials, and energy. Using predictive analytics, CDTs can suggest optimal use patterns that reduce unnecessary waste. For example, if a certain production line is consuming more electricity than needed, the CDT could suggest redistributing this energy to other lines or storing it for future use.
He et al. (2021); Ma et al. (2022); Zheng et al. (2022); Rehman et al. (2023)

CDTs can be programmed to be fully aware of existing environmental laws and regulations. Whenever a new law is enacted or an existing one is updated, this information can be input into the CDT. It will then continuously monitor operations to ensure that the industry is in compliance, reducing the risk of legal repercussions and helping to maintain a commitment to environmental sustainability.
Leng et al. (2021); D'Amico et al. (2022); Zheng et al. (2022) Kalaboukas et al. (2023)

CDTs are often misconceived as job-takers rather than job enablers. Through machine learning algorithms, CDTs can identify skill gaps within the workforce, suggesting targeted training programs. This focus on upskilling can aid in job retention and even job creation in specialized roles, thus providing assurances about job security.
Shi et al. (2022); Maddikunta et al. (2022); Modoni and Sacco (2023); Wang et al. (2024)

Utilizing sensor data and predictive analytics, CDTs can identify potential safety hazards before they become critical incidents. This pre-emptive approach allows industries to take timely corrective measures, thus creating a safer working environment.
Jagatheesaperumal and Rahouti (2022); Modoni and Sacco (2023); Wang et al. (2024)

By handling routine monitoring and data analytics, CDTs free up human workers to engage in more creative, complex problem-solving tasks. This not only enhances job satisfaction but also fosters a sense of autonomy and empowerment among workers.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In the emerging landscape of Industry 5.0, the integration of innovative technologies such as Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) is pivotal for steering industrial processes towards sustainability and inclusivity, particularly in developing nations striving to align with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The study explores the transformative capabilities of CDTs in Industry 5.0, concentrating on India's quest for inclusive and sustainable industrialization in alignment with SDGs. The inclusion of the TOE-HOT framework enriches the research's analytical foundation, providing a nuanced perspective to investigate the multifaceted dynamics of technology, organization, environment, and human aspects within the sphere of industrial evolution. By employing the Best-Worst Method (BWM), Interpretive Structural Modelling (ISM), and MICMAC analysis, the study delves deep into the synergies between industrial strategies, technology, and sustainable development. The findings reveal the paramountcy of the Technological Dimension, emphasizing CDTs strategies like real-time optimization and data analytics, which are instrumental in dynamically adjusting manufacturing processes and fostering alignment with market demands. The research also stresses the roles of various CDTs strategies like strategic alignment, change management, job security, skill augmentation, and environmental compliance in industrial sustainability and inclusivity. The paper concludes with invaluable insights for policymakers, industry leaders, and researchers, emphasizing the necessity for a holistic, interconnected approach to fully harness the potential of CDTs in realizing the aspirations of Industry 5.0 and contributing to India's sustainable industrial advancement by 2030.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: The emergence of Industry 5.0 serves as a milestone in the evolutionary timeline of industrial practices, signalling a shift towards a more human-centric paradigm that synergizes cognitive abilities with technological advancements (Ghobakhloo et al., 2022; Taj and Zaman, 2022; Rosak-Szyrocka et al., 2023). Distinct from its predecessors that predominantly emphasized on automation, Industry 5.0 seeks a harmonious fusion of digital, physical, and biological domains, all underpinned by human intelligence and emotional context (Bednar and Welch, 2020; Ghobakhloo et al., 2022; Nicoletti, 2023). A pivotal component in this multidimensional amalgamation is the Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs). Diverging from traditional digital twins, CDTs are embedded with self-learning algorithms that adapt to dynamic conditions and forecast future scenarios, thus providing an unparalleled platform for real-time data analytics (Rehman et al., 2023). However, what sets them apart even further and aligns them with the human-centric ethos of Industry 5.0 is their ability to integrate human inputs, preferences, and decision-making patterns into their operational framework (Villar et al., 2023; Zhanbayev et al., 2023). This convergence of machine autonomy with human ingenuity enables CDTs to adapt proactively to varying conditions and anticipate future scenarios, revolutionizing fields such as real-time data analytics, predictive maintenance, and resource optimization (Maheshwari et al., 2023). In doing so, CDTs not only optimize industrial processes but also embody the ideals of resource efficiency and environmental sustainability from a human-centric perspective (Al Faruque et al., 2021; Zheng et al., 2022; Leng et al., 2022).

This paradigmatic shift in industrial capabilities intersects with global sustainability objectives, prominently enshrined in the United Nationsâ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) (UNDP, 2017). However, the influence of CDTs in the realm of Industry 5.0, intersects significantly with several Sustainable Development Goals. For instance, in the realm of healthcare, under SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-Being), CDTs offer groundbreaking prospects for personalized patient care and disease management through advanced data analytics, thereby transforming healthcare systems and outcomes. Similarly, the role of CDTs in optimizing energy use aligns them with SDG 7 (Affordable and Clean Energy), as they contribute to enhancing energy efficiency and facilitating the shift towards sustainable energy sources. In urban development, under SDG 11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities), CDTs have the potential to revolutionize urban planning processes. Their application can lead to the creation of smarter, more sustainable urban infrastructures, encompassing efficient traffic systems, improved waste management, and overall sustainable urban development. Furthermore, in the context of SDG 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production), CDTs emerge as key enablers of sustainable production patterns. By facilitating the efficient use of resources and minimizing industrial waste, they contribute significantly to the establishment of a circular economy. Additionally, their role in reducing industrial carbon footprints aligns CDTs with SDG 13 (Climate Action), highlighting their importance in climate change mitigation efforts (Hassani et al., 2022). Among these, Sustainable Development Goal 9 (SDG 9) bears particular relevance to the present study, as it focuses on resilient infrastructure, sustainable industrialization, and innovation. Within SDG 9, Target 9.2 emerges as the specific locus of this research, articulating the need for industrial processes to extend beyond mere efficiency metrics and incorporate inclusivity and environmental sustainability.

For a developing economy like India, with its diverse socio-economic landscape, the integration of SDGsâand particularly Target 9.2âinto its industrialization strategy becomes a compelling imperative (Voola et al., 2022; Mahmood et al., 2023). This research explores how CDTs in the context of Industry 5.0 can be leveraged to achieve the specific tenets of SDG 9.2, thereby fostering a more sustainable and inclusive model of industrialization in India. While the potential of Industry 5.0 and Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) has been recognized globally, there is a pronounced research gap concerning their application and implications in developing economies, particularly in a diverse and rapidly evolving country like India (Dwivedi et al., 2021; Zheng et al., 2022). Addressing this gap is crucial, as the integration and impact of such advanced technologies can vary significantly in different socio-economic contexts. In developing economies, where resources are often constrained and technological infrastructure is still evolving, the adoption of CDTs poses both unique challenges and opportunities. Understanding and addressing these nuances is vital for policymakers, industry leaders, and society at large. For policymakers, this study's findings can inform the creation of supportive frameworks and policies that encourage the adoption of Industry 5.0 technologies in a manner that aligns with national development goals and addresses local challenges. For industry leaders, the insights offer guidance on how to effectively implement CDTs to enhance competitiveness, efficiency, and sustainability. Lastly, for society, this research provides a perspective on how Industry 5.0 can contribute to broader socio-economic development goals, including job creation, skill development, and environmental sustainability. Therefore, this study aims to fill this research gap by providing a comprehensive analysis of how CDTs can facilitate inclusive and sustainable industrialization strategies in alignment with SDG 9.2. By conducting this analysis, the study seeks to answer the following research questions.
R1. What are the key strategies that Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) contribute to achieving inclusive and sustainable industrialization in Industry 5.0?
R2. In what order do the strategies of CDTs influence the achievement of inclusive and sustainable industrialization in the context of Industry 5.0?
R3. Which strategies among the CDTs have the highest driving power in influencing other strategies for inclusive and sustainable industrialization?

In order to fulfil the research objectives of evaluating the key strategies through which Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) influence inclusive and sustainable industrialization in the context of Industry 5.0, this study employs a combined methodology of the Best-Worst Method (BWM) and Interpretive Structural Modelling (ISM). This comprehensive approach allows for an in-depth evaluation of data gathered from various stakeholders active in the fields of Industry 5.0, sustainability, and human-centric industrialization. The study concentrates its inquiry on the manufacturing sector, as this sector is crucial for economic growth, employment, and technological progress. Achieving advancements in inclusivity and sustainability within the manufacturing sector stands to have a ripple effect, substantially accelerating the broader goals of inclusive and sustainable industrialization in emerging economies such as India (Bhatia, 2023; Mukherjee et al., 2023). Given its critical role, the manufacturing sector serves as an ideal setting for investigating the potential of Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) to contribute to the objectives outlined in SDG 9.2, particularly in the Indian context. Initially, an exhaustive literature review is undertaken, supplemented by expert consultations, to identify relevant CDTs strategies that influence inclusive and sustainable industrialization. These strategies are then classified according to the existing TOE-HOT framework and prioritized using the BWM, enabling a systematic appraisal of their relative importance. The application of ISM facilitates the quantification of interrelations among these strategies, thereby providing vital insights into their reciprocal influences and contributions toward attaining SDG 9.2 objectives. The remainder of the manuscript is systematically organized as follows: The second section explores the theoretical underpinnings of Industry 5.0, Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs), Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and specifically, SDG 9 and Target 9.2. The third section explicates the research methodologies employed in this study, including BWM, ISM and the MICMAC analysis. The fourth section delves into the analysis of the gathered results. The fifth section provides an exhaustive discussion of the findings. The sixth section concludes the research, encapsulating its contributions and implications. The seventh and final section addresses potential limitations and suggests avenues for future research in this emerging field.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Introduction to SDGs and their importance
ce:section.ce:para: The concept of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) emerged from the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development; a landmark resolution adopted by all 193 United Nations member states in September 2015 (United Nations, 2015). This global commitment set forth an ambitious framework encompassing 17 interlinked goals, 169 targets, and over 230 indicators aimed at addressing a broad range of social, economic, and environmental challenges by the year 2030 (Chopra et al., 2022; Pandey and Asif, 2022). The criticality of SDGs lies in their capacity to serve as a unifying framework for translating the complex, interdependent challenges of the 21st century into actionable strategies (Maskrey et al., 2023). They offer an integrative approach to problem-solving that accommodates the intricacies of modern global challenges such as poverty, inequality, environmental degradation, peace, and justice (Hales and Birdthistle, 2022). Among these goals, SDG 9 focuses on building resilient infrastructure, promoting inclusive and sustainable industrialization, and fostering innovation (Brodny and Tutak, 2023). Specifically, Target 9.2 aims to promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization, which is essential for generating employment, driving economic growth, and hence, social development (Clement et al., 2023). The pursuit of SDG 9.2 is particularly compelling in the face of increasing global inequities, environmental vulnerabilities, and the advent of the Fourth and Fifth Industrial Revolutions, characterized by the fusion of physical and digital technologies (Kasinathan et al., 2022; Yin and Yu, 2022). Achieving this target necessitates radical innovation and transformative action, especially in the realm of industrial activities. It is here that our research into leveraging Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) in Industry 5.0 gains its critical relevance. By integrating advanced technologies with intelligent, data-driven decision-making, we aim to articulate and demonstrate how CDTs can substantially contribute to achieving SDG 9.2Â bÂ y harmonizing economic growth with environmental stewardship and social inclusivity in developing economies like India.

The transition from Digital Twins (DTs) to Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) signifies a paradigm shift, driven by the multi-dimensional complexities of contemporary industrial landscapes. Digital Twins have served as a linchpin in Industry 4.0, facilitating tasks such as real-time monitoring, predictive maintenance, and data-driven analysis of physical systems (Lenz et al., 2020; Labucay, 2022). However, as industries transition into the Industry 5.0 epoch, which is hallmarked by enhanced human-machine collaboration and a deeper focus on individualized and sustainable production, the limitations of conventional DTs have become increasingly conspicuous. For instance, conventional DTs often struggle with handling the increased data complexity and personalization demands of Industry 5.0. A specific challenge arises in scenarios where real-time data from a multitude of sensors must be synthesized to make immediate, context-sensitive decisions (Eirinakis et al., 2020). Traditional DTs, primarily designed for static or less dynamic environments, lack the capability to autonomously learn from and adapt to such rapidly changing conditions (Liu et al., 2021). For example, in a highly variable manufacturing process, conventional DTs might not effectively predict equipment failure or optimize resource use when production variables frequently change. This limitation becomes particularly evident in scenarios requiring bespoke production configurations to meet unique customer demands, where DTs may fail to adequately adjust to new specifications or integrate customer feedback in real-time. The inability of conventional DTs to dynamically learn and evolve thus hinders their effectiveness in the more agile and personalized environment of Industry 5.0.

It was against this backdrop that the concept of âCognitive Digital Twins' emerged, first introduced by Ahmed El Adl in 2016. Adl defined CDTs as âa digital representation encompassing intelligent capabilities that span across all lifecycle phases of its physical counterpartâ (Adl, 2016). Unlike DTs, which serve mostly as passive replicas for data representation and rudimentary analysis, CDTs are designed to perform complex cognitive tasks. They engage in human-like intellectual activities such as perception, situational reasoning, and autonomous decision-making, leveraging technologies like machine learning and artificial intelligence (Dwivedi et al., 2021; De Kerckhove et al., 2022; Peladarinos et al., 2023). What sets CDTs apart is their ability to respond adaptively to dynamically changing environments and manage unforeseen events in real-time. For example, in the context of SDG 9.2, CDTs can significantly contribute to sustainable industrialization. Imagine a scenario where a manufacturing plant utilizes CDTs to continuously monitor and analyze energy consumption across its operations. By employing advanced predictive analytics, a CDT can foresee periods of higher energy demand and automatically adjust production schedules to utilize energy more efficiently, significantly reducing the plant's carbon footprint. Additionally, CDTs can identify patterns of waste generation and recommend changes in production processes to minimize waste, further contributing to sustainable practices (Kalaboukas et al., 2023).

Moreover, in terms of inclusivity, CDTs enable more personalized and adaptable manufacturing processes. Consider a factory that produces consumer goods. A CDT, through its integration of market data and consumer feedback, can adapt production lines to create customized products that cater to the specific preferences of different consumer groups. This adaptability not only meets diverse customer needs but also addresses community-specific requirements, such as creating products that are more accessible to people with disabilities. Such integration of ethical and social considerations into industrial decision-making exemplifies how CDTs can support a more inclusive approach in line with the aspirational goals of SDG 9.2. This level of responsiveness contributes to creating a more human-centric industrial setting, thus meeting the dual demands of efficiency and inclusivity (Yitmen et al., 2021; D'Amico et al., 2022). This makes CDTs particularly well-suited for complex industrial applications requiring high degrees of automation without sidelining human involvement. Moreover, the cognitive abilities of CDTs are increasingly recognized as indispensable for overcoming challenges associated with the alignment to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), especially in the context of achieving inclusive and sustainable industrialization (SDG 9.2). The need for CDTs, therefore, is not just a matter of technological sophistication. It arises from the real-world complexities of industrial systems, the growing appetite for intelligent and humanized automation, and the urgent requirement to harmonize industrial activities with sustainability imperatives (Kopponen et al., 2022; Ivanov, 2023). While the technological infrastructure for DTs is relatively mature, CDTs represent an evolving frontier that necessitates continued research and development. This is particularly vital because they offer not just incremental improvements over DTs, but a transformative approach to harmonizing automation and human-centricity in the pursuit of sustainability and resilience (Ivanov, 2023). As industries increasingly navigate the complexities of the Industry 5.0 landscape, this study serves as a timely exploration of the untapped potential of CDTs to act as catalysts in achieving the aspirational goals of inclusive and sustainable industrialization (SDG 9.2).

Research on Digital Twins (DTs) spans various domains, from architectural frameworks to specific industrial applications. For example, Tao et al. (2018) laid the foundational architecture for a digital twin shop-floor, elucidating its characteristics and operating mechanisms. Their work holds seminal importance as it operationalizes the DT concept for real-time monitoring and predictive maintenance. SÃ¶derberg et al. (2017) expanded this framework by incorporating real-time geometry to facilitate individualized production, contributing to the granular application of DTs. While most DT research has concentrated on the initial phases of the lifecycle, such as design and development (Tao et al., 2019), Wang and Wang (2019) explored a DT-based system for recycling, recovery, and remanufacturing of waste electrical and electronic equipment, focusing on full lifecycle support. The advent of Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) represents a natural progression from this foundational work on DTs. Researchers have increasingly emphasized the need to imbue DTs with intelligent capabilities, setting the stage for the emergence of CDTs. Semantic technologies, as proposed by Kharlamov et al. (2018), have paved the way for this advancement, offering DTs the potential to understand and interact within complex systems. GÃ³mez-BerbÃ­s and de Amescua-Seco (2019) further advanced this discussion by introducing Semantic Digital Twins (SEDIT) that allow for more dynamic interactions and real-time decision-making. The work of Lu et al. (2020) stands out for its comprehensive framework for developing CDTs, facilitated by a robust toolchain of software and platforms. Abburu et al. (2020) offer a clarifying taxonomy of digital twins, hybrid twins, and cognitive twins, which provides invaluable insights for ongoing research in this area. Also, some work in is in the nuclear field proposed by Park et al. (2022). They applied AR-assisted DT to radioactive waste safety management, ensuring human operators' safety. The studies surveyed indicate a growing, yet insufficiently explored, convergence of DTs and cognitive capabilities. Noteworthy is the recent work by Lv et al. (2023), which underscores the practical application of bio-inspired cognitive architectures in DTs for automated maintenance of machine tools through a self-constructed, self-evaluated, and self-optimized manner. In addition to the DT and CDT-focused research, recent studies have been exploring the broader scope of Industry 5.0. For example, Xu et al. (2021) examined the transition from the technology-focused Industry 4.0 to the value-driven Industry 5.0. Their study, structured around five key questions, aims to clarify the coexistence and distinctions between these two industrial phases. The objective is to foster ongoing debate and discussion in this evolving field, with a commitment to unbiased information sourcing and analysis. Ghobakhloo et al. (2022) explore the transition to Industry 5.0, emphasizing sustainable development over the profit focus of Industry 4.0. They develop a reference model for Industry 5.0, identifying its key technical and functional properties. Utilizing interpretive structural modelling and a comprehensive literature review, the authors outline 16 sustainable development functions integral to Industry 5.0. Maddikunta et al. (2022) demonstrate that the prospective application of Industry 5.0 technologies, such as the seamless exchange of sensor data across networks and the implementation of autonomous systems, contributes to heightened levels of customer satisfaction and confers greater value upon organizations. This phenomenon encompasses various areas such as personalized customization, user-centric design, and cooperative automation. Shahbakhsh et al. (2022) conducted a comprehensive literature review to examine recent developments in the field. The proposal put forth was for the industry to expand its focus beyond the products that were prevalent in the preceding industrial revolutions and instead prioritize Industry 5.0 as a means of propelling itself towards âMaritime 5.0â or âShipping 5.0â. Furthermore, Leng et al. (2022) explored the concept of Industry 5.0, emphasizing its role in enhancing human well-being and sustainable development. The study reviews Industry 5.0's evolution, focusing on its three main characteristics: human-centricity, sustainability, and resiliency. They propose a tri-dimensional system architecture for Industry 5.0, covering technical, reality, and application aspects. Later, Ghobakhloo et al. (2023a,b) conducted a study to clarify the concept of Industry 5.0, addressing societal challenges linked to digital industrialization. The research involved a detailed literature review, leading to an architectural design for Industry 5.0. It highlights Industry 5.0's role in resolving socio-economic and environmental issues overlooked by Industry 4.0. Mukherjee et al. (2023) studied the barriers to the adoption of Industry 5.0 in the Indian manufacturing context. In their study they briefly discussed about the barriers and their mitigating startegies and also propose the GRID framework in order to tackle these barriers.

These broader explorations into Industry 5.0 complement our focus on CDTs, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the current industrial revolution. Specifically, the unique attributes and untapped potentials of Cognitive Digital Twins in aligning with sustainability and inclusivity objectives within the Industry 5.0 paradigm remain less explored. This gap underscores the significance of our research. The convergence of these diverse elements within Industry 5.0 sets the stage for our current research endeavor, emphasizing the need to investigate CDTs not only as advanced technological interfaces but as integral components fostering sustainable and human-centric industrial systems.

In reviewing the existing literature, it becomes apparent that there is a substantive body of work examining Digital Twins (DTs) in the context of advancement in futuristic industrialization, ranging from real-time monitoring to predictive maintenance (Tao et al., 2018; Knapp et al., 2017; SÃ¶derberg et al., 2017). Similarly, early contributions in the realm of Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) have begun to emerge, focusing on their enhanced capabilities like semantic understanding, intelligent decision-making, and adaptability (Kharlamov et al., 2018; Zheng et al., 2022; Lv et al., 2023). However, these studies, while technologically oriented, often do not extend to how CDTs contribute to sustainability and inclusivity. For example, Zheng et al. (2022) delve deeply into the cognitive abilities of CDTs in data processing but overlook their application in enhancing sustainable industrial practices. This gap underscores the need for research that bridges CDTs' technological advancements with SDG 9.2's goals of inclusive and sustainable industrialization (Hassani et al., 2022). The existing literature primarily views CDTs through a technological lens, expounding on their cognitive abilities but rarely extending the discourse to their potential contribution towards sustainability and inclusivity (Zheng et al., 2022; Kalaboukas et al., 2023). Even in studies that focus on the intersection of CDTs and sustainability, the exploration is often narrowed down to environmental gains or process efficiencies, rather than an integrated approach that also encompasses social and economic dimensions (FernÃ¡ndez et al., 2019; Ali et al., 2021). For example, FernÃ¡ndez et al. (2019) analyze CDTs' role in reducing environmental impact in manufacturing but do not extend the discussion to include social inclusivity or broader industrial sustainability. Furthermore, most existing studies restrict their scope to specific industry sectors or case applications, limiting generalizability. Even though Park et al. (2022) have applied augmented reality-assisted DTs in the nuclear field, it doesn't necessarily account for broader industrial applications where CDTs can offer both technological and sustainable advantages. This sector-specific focus diminishes the ability to draw cross-sectoral implications, which is particularly critical when considering the universality of SDGs. Another gap lies in the unaddressed complexity of aligning high levels of automation with human-centricity. As industries transition into the Industry 5.0 paradigm, the balance between technological sophistication and human involvement becomes increasingly critical, an area where CDTs are hypothesized to have significant potential (Longo et al., 2023). Additionally, one notable research gap in existing literature is the theoretical foundation upon which these studies are based. Strategy identification and prioritization in the realm of Cognitive Digital Twins have employed various theoretical frameworks; however, to the best of our knowledge, none have utilized the TOE-HOT framework as a guiding lens. This represents a significant gap given the comprehensive nature of the TOE-HOT framework, which allows for an integrative analysis that can cover technological, organizational, environmental, human, organizational, and technological aspects. Moreover, in terms of methodological innovation, while various tools have been employed for strategy identification in previous research, the use of the Best-Worst Method (BWM) and Interpretive Structural Modelling (ISM) specifically in the context of inclusive and sustainable industrial development represents a novel approach. BWM offers a systematic and reliable way of identifying the most and least important criteria in complex decision-making scenarios, which is crucial for prioritizing strategies in the rapidly evolving landscape of Industry 5.0. Similarly, ISM provides a structured approach to analyze the relationships among different strategies, offering a comprehensive view of how various factors interact and influence each other in the pursuit of sustainable industrialization. The combined use of these methods in our study provides a unique and robust framework for understanding and prioritizing strategies that can drive inclusive and sustainable development in Industry 5.0.

The aforementioned gaps accentuate the need for a more nuanced understanding of CDTs' role, not merely as advanced technological entities but as critical tools for achieving inclusive and sustainable industrial development in the Industry 5.0 era. This study aims to address these gaps, contributing to the literature by exploring the potential of CDTs in harmonizing the dual imperatives of automation and human-centricity, all within the framework of sustainable industrial development.

In line with the multifaceted nature of Industry 5.0 and its implication on sustainable development, our study employs a conjoined theoretical paradigm, integrating the Technological, Organizational, and Environmental (TOE) framework with the Human, Organizational, and Technological (HOT) framework. This composite framework affords us a holistic perspective to examine the interplay between technological innovation, organizational dynamics, and human-centric elements in the context of sustainable and inclusive industrialization. These tenets fundamentally alter the research lens from merely focusing on efficiency and profitability to incorporating a human-centric and environmentally responsible approach in the industrial landscape. The TOE framework, substantiated by extant research (Raj and Jeyaraj, 2022; Aligarh et al., 2023; Das and Bala, 2023), serves as an instrumental tool for identifying pivotal strategies that facilitate technological innovations, particularly during their nascent phases of organizational diffusion. This framework empowers us to identify the technological innovations, organizational mechanisms, and environmental policies that catalyze the seamless integration of Industry 5.0 features, such as Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs), into the manufacturing sector, thereby influencing sustainability indices in alignment with SDG 9.2 objectives. Complementarily, the HOT framework has been acknowledged for its comprehensive reach across various research domains (Mohanraj et al., 2023; Nilashi et al., 2023). It underscores the criticality of human and organizational dimensions, alongside technological elements, in ensuring effective adoption and diffusion of innovations. By incorporating the HOT framework, our study extends its scope to assess the sociotechnical attributes and human-centric aspects that amplify the effectiveness of CDTs in sustainable and inclusive industrialization. In reviewing the literature, we observe key contributions across technological, organizational, and human strategies. Technological innovations, notably in advanced manufacturing and digitalization, have been widely examined for their capability to promote sustainable industrial practices (Kurniawan et al., 2022). Likewise, organizational measures like skill development and stakeholder engagement have been explored for their contribution to achieving SDG 9.2 targets (Cherrafi et al., 2022). Recent scholarship accentuates the role of human strategies, such as workforce training and participation, in driving the safe deployment of sustainable practices (de Jesus and MendonÃ§a, 2018). By merging the TOE and HOT frameworks, as corroborated by previous literature (Orji et al., 2019; Feng et al., 2021), our research captures the multi-dimensionality of the strategies that govern the application of CDTs in Industry 5.0, targeting the objectives of SDG 9.2. We aim to advance the extant body of knowledge and inform policymaking by delivering a comprehensive analysis of the crucial strategies (as shown in Table 1 ) affecting sustainable and inclusive industrialization. Our findings promise to yield actionable insights for policymakers, industry stakeholders, and academicians focused on fortifying sustainable practices within the realm of Industry 5.0.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Identification of strategies related to CDTs in promoting inclusive and sustainable industrialization
ce:section.ce:para: The theoretical decision-making framework presented in this research extends key dimensions crucial for implementing strategies that align with inclusive and sustainable industrialization, notably underscored in SDG 9.2. The dimensions addressed in this framework comprise technological, organizational, environmental, and human aspects. By attending to these dimensions, organizations can more holistically integrate Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) to achieve the dual objectives of inclusivity and environmental sustainability within the broader scope of Industry 5.0.

Each of these dimensions hosts a variety of strategic elements that have been discerned through a comprehensive examination of existing literature and sector-specific expertise (as elaborated in Table 1). These strategic elements function as the pillars for ensuring the successful adoption and deployment of CDTs in fostering an industrial environment that is not only technologically advanced but also socially inclusive and environmentally sustainable.

Technological Dimension: The technological dimension centres on the deployment of Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) to stimulate both inclusivity and sustainability in the context of Industry 5.0. These technological strategies embody a blend of external and internal technological innovations, both in processes and equipment, and have been informed by previous studies in the field of technology adoption (Rejeb et al., 2022). This dimension focuses on embracing technologies that not only augment resource efficiency and curtail waste but also integrate human inputs and preferences into their operational framework, thereby adding a layer of inclusivity to technological solutions. Specific practices within this dimension include the utilization of CDTs for predictive maintenance and real-time analytics (Unal et al., 2022), the incorporation of various sensors and connected devices, CDTs can help monitor workplace conditions in real-time, ensuring that worker safety and well-being (Liu et al., 2022; Yin et al., 2023) and lastly, to analyze market trends, thereby helping industries to avoid both overproduction and stock-outs in order to promote sustainability. These strategies collectively contribute to minimizing risks and advancing the objectives of SDG 9.2 in the industrial sector.

Organizational Dimension: This dimension specifically addresses the organizational infrastructures and policies vital for harnessing Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) in Industry 5.0 settings to meet the milestones set by Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 9. Citing academic works such as Lu et al. (2020) and Ghobakhloo et al. (2023a,b), we emphasize the necessity of educational initiatives targeted at upskilling workers in the usage of CDTs. Such training promotes a culture of safety and inclusivity by facilitating digital dexterity, thereby ensuring a seamless human-machine collaboration (Lu et al., 2022; Mourtzis et al., 2022). Also, companies can set specific sustainability metrics that are continuously monitored by the CDT, ensuring alignment with broader sustainable development goals (Kalaboukas et al., 2023). Lastly, with real-time compliance tracking, CDTs can alert organizations to any breaches in environmental regulations or ethical norms, allowing for immediate corrective action (Ãnal et al., 2023). By fostering these organizational attributes, we contribute to laying a foundation for both inclusive and sustainable industrialization, in line with SDG 9.2.

Environmental Dimension: This dimension concentrates on an organization's commitment to sustainable, eco-friendly practices facilitated by CDTs, aimed at enhancing cleaner production, lowering energy use, and minimizing waste. Utilizing CDTs, organizations can model energy consumption patterns, enabling the formulation of data-driven strategies for reducing carbon footprints, an approach corroborated by studies such as He et al. (2021) and Arsiwala et al. (2023). Moreover, this dimension accentuates the need for strict adherence to environmental regulations, which can be simulated and evaluated through digital twins (Mylonas et al., 2021). It also highlights the role of sustainability and inclusivity in optimizing supply chains for minimal environmental impact (Sharma et al., 2021; Walker et al., 2021). In this way, organizations can navigate the complex realms of industrial sustainability and inclusivity through CDTs, thereby contributing strategic insights toward achieving SDG 9 and its sub-goal of inclusive and sustainable industrialization.

Human Dimension: Human Dimension: This facet emphasizes an organization's commitment to cultivating a humane work environment, facilitated by Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs), which aligns with the objectives of SDG 9.2. Utilizing predictive analytics and sensor data, CDTs empower organizations to identify and mitigate safety hazards, corroborated by contemporary research (Eirinakis et al., 2020; Sasikumar et al., 2023). Additionally, the dimension stresses the importance of open communication channels for workers to report unsafe conditions without the fear of retribution (Islam et al., 2023). Skill augmentation is another focus, with CDTs identifying workforce skill gaps and suggesting targeted training programs, an approach that strengthens job security, as confirmed by research (BÃ©cue et al., 2020; Yitmen et al., 2021). Furthermore, well-being analytics and ethical decision-making algorithms within CDTs assess both the physical and mental wellness of workers, ensuring an ethically balanced, healthy work environment (Wang et al., 2022; vanâLopik et al., 2023). Lastly, the dimension highlights the potential for CDTs to free employees from monotonous tasks, fostering a sense of autonomy and job satisfaction. Collectively, these human-centric strategies facilitate an inclusive and sustainable industrial setting, contributing significantly to the actualization of SDG 9.2.

The integration of Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) in promoting inclusive and sustainable industrialization is manifest in multiple dimensionsâtechnological, organizational, environmental, and human. Our study reveals that the adoption of such multi-faceted approaches not only contributes to operational efficiency and environmental sustainability but also significantly enhances workplace safety and employee well-being. Leveraging CDTs, organizations can proactively identify and mitigate risks, facilitate open communication, and focus on continuous skill augmentation, as substantiated by key literature (Yitmen et al., 2021; GarcÃ­a et al., 2022; Chen et al., 2023). These collective practices pave the way for a safer, more inclusive working environment while making tangible contributions to achieving Sustainable Development Goal 9.2 and fostering an industrial landscape that is not just technologically advanced but also socially equitable and environmentally responsible.

The present research employed a three-phase methodology to evaluate how Cognitive Digital Twins (CDTs) contribute to achieving inclusive and sustainable industrialization within the framework of Industry 5.0, particularly in alignment with SDG 9.2 objectives. The methodological flow is visually depicted in Fig. 1 and consists of three primary stages. In the initial phase, a comprehensive literature review was undertaken to gather insights from existing academic publications. Keywords pertinent to Industry 5.0, Cognitive Digital Twins, SDGs, and specifically SDG 9 and Target 9.2 were used for search queries in various scholarly databases. The articles selected for review were restricted to those published in English. Strategies associated with CDTs that influence inclusive and sustainable industrialization were extracted, later corroborated through expert consultation and empirical analysis. The second stage involved qualitative interviews with industry executives to validate and fine-tune the strategies identified in the literature review. The Best-Worst Method (BWM) was employed to prioritize these strategies, determining their significance in achieving the specific tenets of SDG 9.2. To ensure a comprehensive understanding, diverse sectors within the manufacturing industry were included to assess the replicability of the findings. In the terminal phase, Interpretive Structural Modelling (ISM) was utilized to dissect the intricate relationships among the pre-identified strategies. This resulted in a multi-level hierarchical structure that scrutinized the interdependencies and driving forces behind these strategies. The MICMAC analysis further categorized the strategies into different layers based on their influence and dependency.

By synergizing the results from BWM, ISM, and MICMAC analyses, the research offers an in-depth understanding of how CDTs can be leveraged to facilitate inclusive and sustainable industrialization, aligning with the objectives of SDG 9.2. This methodological approach enriches the current discourse by elucidating the relationships, significance, and impact of these strategies, particularly within the context of India's manufacturing sector. Stakeholders can hence use these insights to make data-driven decisions for the incorporation of CDTs in building a more sustainable and inclusive industrial landscape.

The best-worst method (BWM) was selected for prioritizing strategies in this study because it is a consistent and efficient method that can be used to rank a large number of strategies with fewer pairwise comparisons. The extensive utilization of BWM can be attributed to its numerous advantages compared to other commonly employed MCDM techniques, such as âAnalytic Hierarchy Process (AHP)â and âfuzzy AHP.â According to Rezaei (2015), BWM demonstrates a reduced need for pairwise assessments in comparison to AHP, while maintaining reliable outcomes. Another advantage of employing the Best-Worst Method (BWM) is that the inclusion of integers in the ranking procedure decreases computational intricacy, as opposed to the utilization of fractional values in the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) (Tarei et al., 2021). One additional advantage of the Best-Worst Method (BWM) lies in its heightened reliability in generating the optimal weight when compared to alternative Multiple Criteria Decision Making (MCDM) methodologies. Furthermore, it exhibits greater resilience compared to alternative approaches (Rezaei, 2015; 2016). The BWM method works by comparing each strategy to standard strategies and then assigning weights to the strategies based on their relative importance. The five-step approach to BWM was adapted from Gupta et al. (2023) work and is described in detail.
